Expand - Collapse

  • Maximize Return on

    Our Time Investment

    • What do we sell?
      • Product Line
        • Personal Internet Account
          • description
            • One click sign up.
            • Zero barriers for new customers.
            • (No address or credit card forms.)
            • Contains anything users want to put there.
            • Privacy settings (easy to use)
            • Use 3rd party services to accomplish common tasks.
            • DropBox, Delicious, Flikr, Google Docs
            • Partnerships?
            • All apps accessible from one place.
            • Only the apps you need, none of the ones you don't
            • Personal ID: OpenID, passwords, etc
            • This could turn into a kind of social network!?
          • Customer Economics
            • complimentary products
            • alternatives
        • Mainframe Internet Account
          • description
            • Used by businesses and organizations.
            • One click sign up.
            • Zero barriers for new customers.
            • (No address or credit card forms.)
            • Contains anything they want to put there.
            • Industrial strength storage and application hosting.
            • Designed for data management.
            • Use 3rd party services to accomplish common tasks.
            • DropBox, Delicious, Flikr, Google Docs
            • Partnerships?
            • All apps accessible from one place.
            • Only the apps you need, none of the ones you don't
            • Employees need a personal internet account to access the mainframe.
            • Employers grant employees privileges on the mainframe per personal internet account.
            • Mainframe applications become available in activated personal internet accounts.
            • Can be hosted or installed on a private network?
          • Customer Economics
            • complimentary products
            • alternatives
        • Internet / Web Application Services
          • description
            • Web applications which can be "installed" on mainframe and personal internet accounts.
            • Customer management, collaboration, etc.
            • All the typical web appy things.
          • Customer Economics
            • complimentary products
              • Computers
              • Web browsers
              • Mobile devices with web browsers.
              • There are a zillion web apps that could be considered complimentary.
              • Mobile applications.
              • Even desktop applications can be complimentary.
            • alternatives
              • There are a zillion alternatives to using our web applications.
              • We can't name them all, but there are a few noteworthy ones:
                • Google Apps
                • Zimbra Apps
                • Zoho Apps
                • Mobile Apps
              • And it is important not to forget desktop applications
                • Many applications are built out of a gross overuse of Microsoft Excel
                • Obviously Microsoft Excel and Access have been very powerful tools for many businesses.
              • And privately hosted applications too:
                • There are canned software systems for almost every industry.
                • Many run on Microsoft SQL servers.
              • And don't forget pen and paper.
        • Internet / Web Middleware Services
          • description
            • Web application hosting.
            • Data hosting and management.
            • Application deployment
            • Consulting
          • Customer Economics
            • alternatives
              • There are no products that directly compete.
              • But there are plenty of products that could provide competition in the future.
              • Developers could simply build their own tools.
              • On the platform of their choice:
                • Google App Engine
                • Amazon Web Services
                • Other specialized cloud hosting services.
                • Their own server clusters.
                • In the browser with HTML 5
            • complimentary products

        • Web application promotions, sales, distribution / deployment.

          aka: The app store.

          • description
            • An application store.
            • Owners of personal internet accounts and mainframes can shop for apps.
            • Great search / recommendation engine is key to success.
            • The more apps it has the more users it gets.
            • The more users it gets, the more apps it has.
            • The real value is achieved with a network effect.
            • When a tipping point is reached:
              • Charge developers to host in the store.
              • Allow developers to advertise their apps (for a fee).
              • Other ways of extracting value?
            • Charge developers for a cut of paid applications.
            • Free applications are hosted free.
          • Customer Economics
            • alternatives
              • iTunes app store
              • Android app store
              • Google application store.
              • Web application directories (there are a lot of them)
            • complimentary products
              • Internet enabled devices including:
                • Web browser.
                • Computer
                • Laptop
                • Phone w/ browser
                • Phone reading app
              • How can we use these devices in unique and interesting ways
                to deliver the store and facilitate transactions?
        • Developer Tools
          • description
            • Applications that ease the development of software.

            • We are mostly interested in developer tools for
              applications that run somewhere on our platform.

            • These tools would be similar to what Adobe offers, but for web apps.
          • Customer Economics
            • alternatives
              • Adobe developer and designer products.
              • A text editor and programming / design knowledge.
              • Apple SDK
              • Windows SDK and API
              • iPhone and iPad SDK
              • Blackberry SDK
              • Firefox extension system (extension builder and JetPack)
              • Chrome extension system
              • Hmmmm, these are all platforms. What does that say?
              • Developers like platforms.
            • complimentary products
              • Computer
              • Web browser
              • Text editor
              • Others?
        • Consumer Information
          • description
            • Articles on our website.
            • All about technology and consumers / businesses / organizations.
            • Link bait: Valuable content that people constantly link to (ex: Life Hacker)
          • Customer Economics
            • alternatives
              • Any other information on the web.
                • There is a lot of information on the web.
                • So this product category has been commoditized.
                • So we're not going rely on this for revenue.
                • The competition is too tight.
              • Books and Magazines
                • There are a lot of good book publishers that grip this industry
                • So this product category has been commoditized.
                • So we're not going rely on this for revenue.
                • The competition is too tight.
              • So this product category has been commoditized.
                • So we're not going rely on this for revenue.
                • Instead, we'll create quality content to build brand equity.
                • Increase the value of our virtual real estate (our website)
                • Create sales leads
            • complimentary products
              • Internet enabled reading devices including:
                • Web browser.
                • Computer
                • Laptop
                • Phone w/ browser
                • Phone reading app
              • How can we use these devices in unique and interesting ways to deliver our content?
        • Developer Information
          • description
            • Articles on our website.
            • All about software technology, missing manuals, how tos, tutorials, etc.
            • Link bait: Valuable content that people constantly link to (ex: Wikipedia)
          • Customer Economics
            • alternatives
              • Any other information on the web.
                • There is a lot of information on the web.
                • So this product category has been commoditized.
                • So we're not going rely on this for revenue.
                • The competition is too tight.
              • Books
                • There are a lot of good book publishers that grip this industry
                • So this product category has been commoditized.
                • So we're not going rely on this for revenue.

              • So this product category has been commoditized.
                • So we're not going rely on this for revenue.
                • Instead, we'll create quality content to build brand equity.
                • Increase the value of our virtual real estate (our website)
                • Create sales leads
                • Attract new members.

      • How to sell it?
    • How do we make money?
      • Capturing Value
        • Geographic markets. (All products)
          • United States (initially)
          • Canada?
          • UK?
        • Personal Internet Accounts
          • Revenue Mechanism
            • Unrestricted use; no revenue.
            • Users will not be able to use a Mainframe Internet account
              without a Personal Internet Account
            • Sign up should be as simple as possible
            • No barriers!

            • Indirect Revenue

              • Ease the sale of paid services.

              • Build brand equity.
            • Direct Revenue
              • None
          • Economics of Scale
            • Pricing
            • Breakeven
        • Mainframe Internet Accounts
          • Revenue Mechanism
            • Unrestricted use; no revenue.
            • Users will not be able to use a Mainframe Internet account
              without a Personal Internet Account
            • Sign up should be as simple as possible
            • No barriers!

            • Indirect Revenue

              • Ease the sale of paid services.

              • Build brand equity.
            • Direct Revenue
              • None
          • Economics of Scale
            • Pricing
            • Breakeven
        • Internet / Web Application Services
          • Revenue Mechanism
            • Most consumer facing apps will be built by 3rd party developers.
            • Using all three usage restrictions:
            • Restricted use; pay ahead service / subscription fees.
            • Freemium; limited revenue.
            • Unrestricted use; no revenue.
            • Developers may use any revenue mechanism they choose.
            • Consumer facing applications.
              • Indirect Revenue

                • build brand equity

                • drive sales of paid applications

              • Direct Revenue
                • Collect service / subscription fees. (Pay ahead on demand.)
              • The majority of consumer applications will only bring indirect revenue.
            • Business oriented applications.
              • Direct Revenue
                • Collect service / subscription fees. (Pay ahead on demand.)
              • Indirect Revenue

                • build brand equity

                • drive sales of paid applications

              • The majority of business oriented applications will be expected to generate direct revenue
          • Economics of Scale
            • Pricing
            • Breakeven
        • Internet / Web Middleware Services
          • Revenue Mechanism
            • For developers and software companies which
              could use a ready data management system
              and existing distribution mechanisms for their applications.
              • Direct Revenue
                • Restricted use; pay ahead service / subscription fees.
                • The majority of software developer oriented services will be expected to generate direct revenue
                • Notice that we say developer oriented "services" to describe our direct revenue source.
                • Services do *not* include the open software itself, which is free by its very nature.
                • Services do include hosting, data management,
                  application deployment, application hosting and storage,
                  consulting, web development, etc.
              • Indirect Revenue
                • Freemium; limited revenue.
                • Unrestricted use; no revenue.

                • build brand equity

                • drive sales of paid applications

                • This catagory includes all of our open source software.
                • Any services associated with our software fall into the *direct revenue* category.
          • Economics of Scale
            • Pricing
            • Breakeven
        • Developer Tools
          • Revenue Mechanism
            • Direct Revenue
              • Freemium; limited revenue.
            • Indirect Revenue
              • Freemium; limited revenue.
          • Economics of Scale
            • Pricing
            • Breakeven
        • Consumer Information
          • Revenue Mechanism
            • Indirect Revenue
              • Unrestricted use; no revenue.

              • build brand equity

              • drive sales of paid applications

              • Increase the incoming link count to our website
              • Good page rank SEO is really valuable equity.
              • Increase the value of our internet real estate holdings.
          • Economics of Scale
            • Pricing
            • Breakeven
        • Developer Information
          • Revenue Mechanism
            • Indirect Revenue
              • Unrestricted use; no revenue.

              • build brand equity

              • drive sales of paid applications

              • Increase the incoming link count to our website
              • Good page rank SEO is really valuable equity.
              • Increase the value of our internet real estate holdings.
          • Economics of Scale
            • Pricing
            • Breakeven
        • Web application promotions, sales, distribution / deployment.
          aka: The app store.
          • Revenue Mechanism
            • Direct Revenue
              • Charge developers for a cut of paid applications.
            • Indirect Revenue
              • Free applications are hosted free.

              • build brand equity

              • drive sales of paid applications

            • Future Revenue
              • The more apps it has the more users it gets.
              • The more users it gets, the more apps it has.
              • The real value is achieved with a network effect.
              • When a tipping point is reached:
                • Charge developers to host in the store.
                • Allow developers to advertise their apps (for a fee).
                • Other ways of extracting value?
          • Economics of Scale
            • Pricing
            • Breakeven
